page.title: 16HEADCORN'S BUILDING MATERIAL
page.content: Many of the houses in the area display {typical Wealden characteristics}of style and materials. There are several very fine examples of{half-timbered {Tudor houses.}Yeomen's houses with main beams of Wealden Oak and with wattle and daub infilling of hazel. The foundation courses are of brick or stone. The{smaller cottages}of the 18th. and 19th. centuries are usually weatherboarded. Local timber was used and is now white painted. Roofing is of locally made clay Kent peg tiles. {The Parish Church}and the older part of the{Primary School}are of Kent Ragstone and Bethersden Marble. The former is a sandstone from the ridge to the N. and the latter a fossil bearing conglomerate. There are also many{cottages and larger houses}built in red brick from the old Pluckley or Frittenden works.
